Aristotle was born around 384 BC in the ancient
Greek kingdom of Macedonia

9.text:
where his father was the royal doctor.
He grew up to be arguably the most influential

13.text:
philosopher ever, with modest nicknames like
‘the master’ and simply ‘the philosopher’.

19.text:
His first big job was tutoring Alexander the
Great who, soon after, went out and conquered

24.text:
Aristotle then headed off to Athens, worked
with Plato for a bit, then branched out on

28.text:
his own. He founded a little school called
the Lyceum. French secondary schools - ‘the

34.text:
lycees’ - are named in honour of this venture.
He liked to walk about while teaching and

43.text:
His many books are actually lecture
notes

47.text: Aristotle was fascinated by how many things

49.text:
actually work: how does a chick grow in an
egg? How do squid reproduce?

54.text: Why does a plant grow well in one place

55.text:
and hardly at all in another? And - most
importantly - what makes a human life, and

60.text:
a whole society, go well?
For Aristotle, philosophy was about practical

64.text:
wisdom.
Here are four big philosophical questions

67.text:
he answered.
One : what makes people happy?

71.text:
In the ‘Nicomachean’ ethics (the book
got it’s name because it was edited by his

75.text:
son, Nicomachus) Aristotle set himself the
task of identifying the factors that lead

80.text: people to have a good life - or not.

83.text:
He suggested that good and successful people
all possess distinct ‘virtues’ - and proposed

88.text:
that we should get better at identifying what
these are, so that we can nurture them in

92.text:
ourselves and honour them in others. Aristotle
zeroed in on 11 virtues

103.text:
Aristotle also observed that every virtue
seems to be bang in the middle of two vices.

108.text:
It occupies what he termed ‘the golden mean’
[a perfectly balanced plank on triangle] between

111.text:
two extremes of character.
For example, in Book IV of his Ethics, under

115.text:
the charming title of ‘Conversational Virtues:
wit, buffoonery and boorishness’, Aristotle

121.text:
looks at ways people are better or worse at
conversation. (knowing how to have a good

125.text:
conversation is one of the ingredients of
the good life, Aristotle recognised).

130.text:
Some people go wrong because they lack a subtle
sense of humour: that’s the “boor”,

135.text:
someone “useless for any kind of social
intercourse, because he contributes nothing

141.text:
But others carry humour to excess: ‘The
buffoon cannot resist a joke, sparing neither

146.text:
himself, nor anybody else provided that he
can raise a laugh, and saying things that

150.text: a man of taste would never dream of saying.’

153.text:
So the ‘virtuous’ person is in the golden
mean in this area: witty, but tactful.

159.text:
A particularly fascinating moment is when
Aristotle draws up a table of ‘too little’

163.text:
‘too much’ and ‘just right’ around
the whole host of virtues.

167.text:
We can’t change our behaviour in any of
these areas just at the drop of a hat. But

170.text:
change is possible, eventually. ‘Moral goodness’
says Aristotle ‘ is the result of habit’.

176.text:
It takes times, practice, encouragement. So,
Aristotle thinks, people who lack virtue should

181.text:
be understood as unfortunate rather than wicked.
What they need is not scolding or being thrown

186.text: in prison but better teachers, more guidance.

194.text:
The blockbuster art at that time was tragedy.
Athenians watched gory plays at community

199.text:
festivals in huge open air theatres. Aeschylus,
Euripides and Sophocles were household names.

205.text:
Aristotle wrote a ‘how to write great plays’
manual: the Poetics. It’s packed with great

209.text:
tips.
For example, make sure to use:

212.text:
peripeteia - a change in fortune, when for
the hero things go from great to awful [in

217.text:
Titanic, Leonardo de Caprio gets Kate Winslow
(great) then they hit the iceberg (awful)

222.text:
and
anagnoresis - a moment of dramatic revelation

225.text:
when suddenly the hero works out their life
is a catastrophe

228.text: But what is tragedy actually for? What is

230.text:
the point of a whole community coming together
to watch horrible things happening to the

233.text:
lead characters? Like Oedipus (in the play
by Sophocles) who by accident, kills his father,

238.text:
gets married to his mother, finds out he’s
done these things [on screen: anagnoresis!)

240.text:
and gouges out his own eyes in remorse and
despair.

243.text:
Aristotle’s answer is Katharis - which is
greek for … Catharsis.

247.text: Catharsis is a kind of cleaning - you get

250.text:
rid of bad stuff. In this case cleaning up
our emotions, specifically our confusions

254.text:
around the feelings of fear and pity.
We’ve got natural problems here: we are

258.text:
hard hearted: we don’t give pity where it
is deserved. And we’re prone to either exaggerated

263.text: fears or not getting frightened enough

266.text:
Tragedy reminds us that:
terrible things can befall decent people including

269.text:
ourselves): a small flaw can lead to a whole
life unravelling

272.text:
and so
we should have more compassion (or pity) for

275.text:
those whose actions go disastrously wrong.
We need to be collective re-taught these crucial

280.text:
truths on a regular basis. The task of art
- as Aristotle saw it - is to make profound

285.text:
truths about life stick in our minds.
Three: What are friends for?

291.text:
In books eight and nine of the Nicomachean
Ethics Aristotle identifies three different

295.text:
kinds of friendship.
There’s friendship that comes about when

298.text:
each person is seeking fun; their ‘chief
interest is in their own pleasure and the

302.text:
opportunity of the moment’ which the other
person provides. We need other people to have

304.text: a nice time around. We need pleasant companions.

305.text:
[on screen, beer drinking festival]
Then there are friendships that are really

306.text:
strategic acquaintances: ‘they take pleasure
in each other’s company only in so far as

311.text: they have hopes of advantage of it.’

313.text:
[on screen: faux-jovial business meeting]
Then there’s the true friend: Not someone

316.text:
who’s just like you. But someone who isn’t
you - but about whom you care as much as you

320.text:
are about yourself.
The sorrows of a true friend are your sorrows

324.text:
to, their joys are yours. It makes you more
vulnerable - should anything befall this person.

329.text:
But it is hugely strengthening: you are relieved
from the too small orbit of your own thoughts

333.text:
and worries, you expand into the life of another,
together you become larger, cleverer, more

338.text:
resilient, more fair minded. You share virtues
and cancel out each other’s defects. Friendship

343.text:
teaches us what we ought to be. It is - quite
literally - the best part of life.

348.text:
Four: how can ideas cut through in a busy
world?

353.text:
Like a lot of people, Aristotle was struck
by the fact that the best argument doesn’t

356.text: always win the debate or the battle.

359.text: this happens and what we can do about it.

362.text:
He had lots of opportunity for observations:
in Athens lots of decisions were made in public

366.text:
meetings (often in the Agora - the town square);
orators would vie with one another to sway

373.text:
Aristotle plotted the ways audiences and individuals
are influenced by many factors that don’t

379.text:
strictly engage with logic or the facts of
the case.

382.text:
It’s maddening. And many serious people
[especially Plato] can’t stand it. They

387.text: avoid the marketplace and populist debate.

390.text:
Aristotle was more ambitious. He invented
the art of what we still today call Rhetoric:

395.text:
the art of getting people to agree with you.
He wanted thoughtful, serious and well-intentioned

400.text:
people to learn how to be persuasive - to
reach those who don’t agree already.

405.text:
He makes some timeless points: You have to
recognise, acknowledge and sooth people’s

409.text:
fears. You have to see the emotional side
of the issue - is someone’s pride on the

413.text:
line, are they feeling embarrassed - and edge
round it accordingly.

416.text:
You have to make it funny - because attention
spans are short.

419.text:
And you might have to use illustrations and
examples to make your point come alive.
